#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Signs
#Text=Different signs are today a part of the surroundings in built-up areas and along roads .
#Text=Especially in the developed world you can expect to find some kind of signs in pretty much all public areas , both indoors and outdoors .
#Text=Understand

#Text=While probably most travelers visit destinations for other attractions than signs ( and they are often not even considered attractions ) , they are still frequently objects of photography and part of the environment .

#Text=Few foreign travelers would abstain from taking photos of the painted tile street name signs in Spain , iconic pub signs in Britain , kangaroo signs along Australia ’s highways and the neon signs of Las Vegas and Chinatowns around the world .

#Text=The very first time you travel to a country where another alphabet is used , being surrounded by signs in a script you probably cannot make any sense of is likely one of the major factors that make the place feel exotic and even intimidating .
#Text=Road and street signs
#Text=Route signs along the former Route 66 are the obvious example of iconic road signs .
#Text=Other famous routes , roads and hiking trails , also often have a special recognizable type of sign .
#Text=When crossing into another country , province or other area there may be a remarkable “ welcome ” sign or even kind of gate or " arch of triumph " .

column1: #Text=Note that it may not be OK to take photos of or near border crossings , as these are regarded as sensitive security areas .
#Text=Abroad you may see not only traffic signs you have n’t seen before but new variants of familiar signs .
#Text=For instance outside Europe and the US chances are that the text on the eight-sided red stop sign will be something else than “ STOP ” .
#Text=Even in Latin America you will encounter “ PARE ” or “ ALTO ” .
#Text=Signs notifying of dangers that are not commonly found around the world like the polar bear signs on Svalbard are also worth a photo .

#Text=Relatively unique prohibitive signs also belong in this category , like the crossed-out maté gourd on Uruguay an intercity buses or durian fruit in the Singapore MRT system ( though photography is not allowed in the latter ) .
#Text=Cities and towns often have street signs that are aesthetically beautiful like the ones in the Vienna Old town or otherwise iconic .
#Text=Moreover some streets and squares like Broadway or the Red Square are world famous , so while there do n't forget to take a pic of the sign as well !

#Text=Some famous streets ( Champs Elysée in Paris , Unter den Linden in Berlin ) are also marked by street signs that in some cases have become famous in their own right if only as " proof " that you actually were there , so take pictures .
#Text=Streets , squares and roads are often named after important historical persons , events or places .
#Text=Interestingly , they may be named after persons still alive ( countries with authoritarian regimes are almost guaranteed to have these ) .
#Text=And rock fans will probably find AC/DC Lane in Melbourne and the Calle AC/DC in Leganés outside Madrid worth a visit .
#Text=Places

#Text=Whether it be places with funny names like Fucking or places famous for one reason or another like Wacken or Schengen , the entrance sign to the town has often become a common motive for photography .
#Text=Signs for Hollywood and Las Vegas ( see image ) have even become attractions in their own right .
#Text=If a destination is rather small but has a funny or unusual name , road and street signs that include the place ’s name are often among the main attractions .
#Text=This also includes corresponding signs of businesses if such exist .
#Text=Of course some destinations may have names that businesses prefer not to use .
#Text=Mountain peaks , particularly high or low locations , extreme points of countries , continents and such often have a sign informing people that they are at such a location .
#Text=Also , places where important historical people have been born or events have taken place are often marked by a commemorative plaque .
#Text=Rail systems

#Text=Some major urban rail systems have very distinctive signs and logos , the best known probably being the Underground signs at the entrance to and inside the London Tube and the “ Metropolitain ” signs of Paris .
#Text=Also , stations that are remarkably decorated often also feature remarkable station name signs .
#Text=If you travel on named train services , there are often signs on the stations or at least on and inside the wagons themselves .
#Text=In addition , before and after an extraordinary train journey like the Trans-Siberian , do take photos of the station signs too .
#Text=Most modern high speed rail systems have some display showing travel speed .

#Text=If you are fortunate enough to catch the speedometer ( in practice , unless you 're allowed into the driver 's compartment , info screen ) when it shows 300 km/h , 200mph or even more , do take a picture .
#Text=For some this may even be a factor or at least a contributing factor to chose a certain train in the first place .
#Text=Business signs
#Text=Old town s may have signs for businesses from the time where electrical light did n’t exist .

#Text=Sometimes the establishment the sign marks may not be there any longer , sometimes it is , and otherwise the establishment is n't actually that old but just has an old-looking sign to better fit into the environment .
#Text=These can be painted on the walls like murals or signboards mounted on or hanging out of the wall .
#Text=In particular the British Isles are famous for their beautiful pub signs .
#Text=Painted signboards such as the ones seen in Western movies can be seen in the ghost towns of the old west .
#Text=" Guild signs " ( or modern replicas made to look like them ) are another favorite .

column1: #Text=Often , they protrude into the street at a right angle to be better visible .
#Text=Examples include a distinctive striped " barber pole " ( or a pair of scissors ) for barbers , a pretzel for bakers , animals for butchers or restaurants .
#Text=They are often used to invoke ( real or proclaimed ) tradition going back centuries and a " down home " feeling of the " good old days " .
#Text=The modern version of these are neon signs , that have been around for about a century .
#Text=Invented in France , they are probably more often associated with the United States and subsequently East Asia and East Asian communities around the world .
#Text=Actual neon signs used to be more common , but have partially been replaced by LED signs and screens .
#Text=Billboards and street advertisements can also be considered part of this category , however they are not as permanent as the other forms of signage .

#Text=In some cites ( notably the City of London ) you may also find older signs typically cast in metal with heraldic elements accompanied by numbers or letters These were originally signs to private fire brigades ( run by insurance companies ) that a particular building had paid its insurance premium and was thus under that brigade 's protection .
